qas.question: What is the ancient Egyptian hieroglyph for green?
Who was the ruler of the underworld in ancient Egypt?
Why was green facial makeup worn by ancient Egyptians?
Where were scarab beetles worn to protect Egyptians from evil?

context: For the ancient Egyptians, green had very positive associations. The hieroglyph for green represented <a0_0>a growing papyrus sprout<a0_0/>, showing the close connection between green, vegetation, vigor and growth. In wall paintings, the ruler of the underworld, <a1_0><b4_0>Osiris<b4_0/><a1_0/>, was typically portrayed with a green face, because green was the symbol of good health and rebirth. Palettes of green facial makeup, made with malachite, were found in tombs. It was worn by both the living and dead, particularly <b6_0>around the eyes<b6_0/>, <a2_0>to protect them from evil<a2_0/>. Tombs also often contained <b5_0>small green amulets<b5_0/> in the shape of scarab beetles made of malachite, which would protect and give vigor to the deceased. It also symbolized the sea, which was called the "<b3_0>Very Green<b3_0/>."
